title: Unusual Sample Proportion?
question_text:
Four of the choices below describe the population proportion and the sample size for a sampling distribution for proportions.
$0.27$ as a sample proportion would be most unusual for which sampling distribution?

choices.text: This cannot be determined since none of the answer choices would have a nearly normal sampling distribution.

solution:
For all four descriptions, both $np$ and $n(1-p)$ are greater than $10$, so they should all have nearly normal sampling distributions. Choice 'E' is incorrect.

0.27 would be more unusual for a sampling distribution centered at 0.30 than one centered at 0.26, so Choices 'A' and 'B' are incorrect.

Since n is in the denominator, a larger sample size creates a smaller standard deviation.

A smaller standard deviation, in turn, generates a larger z-score and, therefore, a more unusual observation. Choice 'C' is incorrect because it has a smaller sample size.
